0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Multiple sclerosis, Relapsing forms: (initial) 0.0625 mg SUBQ every other day; increase every 2 weeks by 0.0625 mg to the recommended dosage of 0.25 mg every other day
  • Multiple sclerosis, Relapsing forms: (maintenance) 0.25 mg SUBQ every other day
  • Multiple sclerosis, Relapsing forms: (premedication) to alleviate flu-like symptoms, analgesics and/or antipyretics may be given on treatment days

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients under 18 years of age

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Multiple sclerosis, Relapsing forms
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Clinically isolated syndrome

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Hypersensitivity to natural or recombinant interferon beta, human albumin, or to any other component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- Congestive heart failure (CHF), cardiomyopathy, and cardiomyopathy with CHF have been reported
  • -- Monitor patients with comorbid congestive heart failure (CHF) for worsening symptoms; discontinuation may be warranted
  • Dermatologic:
  • -- Injection site necrosis has sometimes required skin grafting; interrupt injections to affected area until fully healed and interrupt therapy until condition resolves if multiple lesions develop
  • -- Injection site reactions (eg, inflammation, pain, hypersensitivity, mass, edema, and nonspecific reactions) have occurred, mostly during the first 3 months of therapy
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Myelosuppression, especially leukopenia, may occur; monitoring recommended
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Severe hepatic injury, including liver failure, has been reported, with increased risk among patients treated with hepatotoxic drugs or with conditions associated with liver injury; monitoring recommended and discontinuation may be warranted
  • --Serum transaminase elevations have been reported; monitoring recommended; dose reduction or discontinuation may be warranted
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Anaphylaxis and other allergic reactions (eg, dyspnea, bronchospasm, tongue edemas, skin rash, urticaria) have been reported; discontinue use if anaphylaxis occurs
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Seizures have been reported with beta-interferon use
  • Psychiatric:
  • -- Depression and suicidality have been reported; consider discontinuation if depression develops
  • Other:
  • -- Flu-like symptom complex may occur

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction (43.6% to 78%), Rash (21%)
  • Hematologic:Decreased lymphocyte count (86%), Leukopenia (10% to 18%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Increased muscle tone (37.8% to 40%), Myalgia (23%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (53%), Headache (50%), Insomnia (21%)
  • Other:Fever (31%), Pain (42%), Shivering (21%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Capillary leak syndrome, Cardiomyopathy, Congestive heart failure
  • Dermatologic:Injection site necrosis (4% to 4.7%)
  • Hepatic:Hepatitis
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Psychiatric:Depression, Suicidal intent

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Interferon beta-1b has both antiviral and immunoregulatory properties . The mechanism by which it exerts its effects in multiple sclerosis (MS) are not clearly understood . It is known, however, that the biologic response-modifying properties of interferon beta-1b are mediated through its interactions with specific cell receptors found on the surface of human cells . Binding of interferon beta-1b to these receptors induces the expression of a number of interferon-induced gene products (e.g., 2',5'-oligoadenylate synthetase, protein kinase, and indoleamine 2, 3-dioxygenase) that are believed to be the mediators of this interferon's biological actions .

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • reconstitute by attaching the prefilled syringe containing the diluent (sodium chloride 0.54% solution) to an intact vial, using the vial adapter
  • slowly inject 1.2 mL of diluent into vial to yield a concentration of 0.25 mg/mL; gently swirl the vial to dissolve drug completely
  • do not shake; if foaming occurs, allow vial to sit undisturbed until foam settles
  • keeping the syringe and vial adapter in place, turn assembly over so vial is on top, and withdraw the appropriate dose into syringe
  • use reconstituted solution immediately or within 3 hours if refrigerated
  • rotate injection sites
  • missed dose: administer as soon as possible; do not give on 2 consecutive days; give next dose 48 hours later

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduction in frequency of clinical exacerbations indicates efficacy in patients with relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis
  • changes in MRI studies may indicate improvement
  • CBC with differential; 1, 3, and 6 months after initiation of therapy, then periodically; frequent monitoring may be required for patients with myelosuppression
  • liver function tests and other blood chemistries; 1, 3, and 6 months after initiation of therapy, then periodically
  • thyroid function tests; every 6 months with history of thyroid dysfunction or as clinically indicated
  • signs and symptoms of liver injury
  • cardiac disease worsening; during initiation and continued treatment, in patients with preexisting congestive heart failure

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Betaseron
    Subcutaneous Powder for Solution: 0.3 MG
  • Extavia
    Subcutaneous Powder for Solution: 0.3 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
INTERFERONS
OVERDOSE: Data are limited. Shivers, myalgias, low grade fever and tachycardia have been reported. ADVERSE EFFECTS: "flu-like" symptoms (fever, chills, tachycardia, headache, malaise, and myalgias), hypotension, seizures, headache, lethargy, fatigue, elevated liver enzymes, leukopenia, & renal insufficiency; dysrhythmias in patients with underlying heart disease. Vomiting, diarrhea, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia occur at high doses.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
INTERFERONS
  • Decontamination: Not indicated; broken down in the gut on oral ingestion.
  • Influenza-like illness: Treat with acetaminophen or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents
  • Hypotensive episode: Transient, usually requires no treatment; 0.9% NaCl 10-20 ml/kg, dopamine, epinephrine if persistent
  • Monitoring of patient: CBC, hepatic & renal function; ECG, calcium, potassium if severe overdose.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
INTERFERONS
Single doses greater than 100-200 million units associated with toxicity.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Tell patient to report symptoms of hepatic failure or seizures.
  • Instruct patient to report worsening depression or suicidal ideation.
  • Side effects may include injection site reactions, leukopenia, asthenia, flu-like symptoms, myalgia, insomnia, abdominal pain, and rash.
  • Counsel patient to report symptoms of worsening preexisting congestive heart failure.
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of injection site necrosis.
  • Teach patient the proper technique for injections and to rotate injection sites.
  • If a dose is missed, advise patient to inject it as soon as possible and maintain a 48-hour interval for the next dose. Do not inject the drug on 2 consecutive days.
